Opposite the shelves, a small counter holds a mortar and pestle, a measuring scale, and a rack of four injection needles. A barred dispensary window connects the pharmacy to the common room.

The door to the Pharmacy is always kept locked. It contains multiple pharmaceuticals developed by Lethica, all of which are based on the Lethic Serum. Lethica and her orderlies know the contents of each bottle by sight. Characters who attempt to steal one of these medications find one at random, as determined by rolling on the Unlabeled Medicine table.

Treasure. The Pharmacy is also stocked with six @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.L887NdWEP5NqHCrQ]{Potions of Healing} (greater) and two sets of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.SztwZhbhZeCqyAes]{Alchemist's Supplies}, which are labelled. The four injection needles contain the same tranquilizer used by the @UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.wYDQmBRsrRo8AAta]{Mutant Nurses}* when they make their Inject attack and has the same effect.

A treatment schedule board hangs adjacent to the dispensary window next to which a file bin contains one of Lethica’s records:

“Godlee—Do not let a patient miss even one dosage. Keep me informed regarding stock amounts and frequency of deliveries from the laboratory.”

L9: Common Room - First Floor.name: L9: Common Room - First Floor
L9: Common Room - First Floor.text:
L9: Common Room - First Floor

The spacious common room is clean and orderly. Cushioned chairs and round tables huddle together in neat clusters, each with simple diversions. Patients sit in passive silence, pick at meals that require no cutlery, and line up at a small pharmacy window for their regimen.

Orderlies keep watch and tend to the patients, guiding them to and from the tables, the corridors, or through wide-open doors leading to an inner courtyard.

Characters are free to interact with the patients here in the Common Room so long as they follow the Code of Conduct. The patients exhibit odd behaviors:

  • A patient tears up pieces of a picture puzzle, reassembling the people portrayed in its scene into a single jumbled malformation.

  • A patient repeats the same numbers over and over, but only when addressed: “6…Go!...9…5…3…6…Go!...9…” (this is the code to the Elevator in the Convalescent Ward, area L6b, which is 9536).

  • A patient keeps a cloth napkin over their face and grows irritated if it is removed.

@UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-rollable-tables.RollTable.MWPtjxYyvICqaADV]{Unlabeled Medicine}

Nurse Godlee. When the characters enter, Nurse Godlee (@UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.wYDQmBRsrRo8AAta]{Mutant Nurse}*) wastes no time introducing herself.

You are approached by an orderly who has no mask. Instead, she wears a porcelain eyepatch over her left eye, painted with the image of an eye that matches her right. She watches the room with hawk-like precision, and her lips form a tight smile as she speaks with you. “I trust you’ve read our code of conduct. I am Nurse Godlee, second to Matron Lethica. It is my duty to make sure your stay at Memory’s Rest is a pleasant and nourishing one. And you are...?”

Godlee keeps her tone composed and professional, knowing that she can be off-putting to newcomers. She emphasizes strict adherence to the sanatorium’s rules and procedures to gauge if the characters are potential assets or threats. If asked about the Lethic Serum or their methods, Godlee deflects by stating that Lethica’s treatment is revolutionary and tailored for each specific patient’s needs.

Development. The conversation with Nurse Godlee is interrupted when a patient rises unsteadily, clutching a tray of food before pitching the tray against the wall with a loud crash. Godlee maintains her composure, directing a nearby orderly to take care of the mess right away as another orderly rushes to the pharmacy window. She advises the patient that accidents happen and that we must remember to control ourselves.

A character who succeeds on a [[/check INS DC 12]] check realizes that Godlee’s words are more than a reprimand—they are a warning. Godlee is carefully concealing her true severity in the presence of the characters. When the orderly returns, Godlee offers the patient two pills (a Hypnotic and Relaxant) from the Pharmacy (area L8) and waits until they have taken the medication. Afterwards, she wishes the characters well and excuses herself to log the incident at the Behavioral Ward’s Nurse’s Station.

L10: Airing Grounds - First Floor.name: L10: Airing Grounds - First Floor
L10: Airing Grounds - First Floor.text:
L10: Airing Grounds - First Floor

The common room leads to an open yard, enclosed on all sides by the brick walls of the sanatorium. A circuitous gravel path winds through manicured hedges, stone benches, and flowering plants, made to resemble a palatial garden.

A solitary patient (neutral, noncombatant human @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.SqZRuJ8lt2KGJBbq]{Commoner}) sits at the far end of the Airing Grounds, facing the southern wall while plotting their means of escape. They have managed to avoid taking their pills and have crushed them into a fine powder. The patient attacks any creature that comes within 5 feet, covering the target in a cloud of pulverized medication. The target must succeed on a [[/save CON DC 15]] saving throw or suffer the effects of the Sedative, Relaxant, Suppressant, and Euphoriant from the Pharmacy (area L8).

The patient screams and takes an action on each of their turns to Dash in an attempt to flee the sanatorium. Roll initiative!

Hugo Intervenes. When the patient screams, a louder bellow emanates from the Second Floor. On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), Hugo (@UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.mkR54wUHh2EX8eY6]{Serum Brute}*) vaults down into the garden through one of the inward-facing windows. If the patient is beyond Hugo’s Blindsight, the other orderlies point the way. If Hugo gets within 10 feet of the patient, he grapples and subdues them easily. “Hugo will help,” he sighs.

Hugo promptly carries the patient to a vacant Recovery Room (area L11d, the room with the Secret Entrance) and restrains them. The orderlies rush to calm any other patients who witnessed the incident to restore order, including the characters.

L11: Recovery Rooms - First Floor, Conva.name: L11: Recovery Rooms - First Floor, Convalescent Ward
L11: Recovery Rooms - First Floor, Conva.text:
L11: Recovery Rooms - First Floor, Convalescent Ward

Each suite contains a narrow bed with crisp white sheets, a bedside table, and a metal chair tucked into the corner.

Most of the seven Recovery Rooms are occupied by current patients during sleeping hours. Nurse Godlee discreetly moves patients to the Second Floor Sedation Hall (area L16) if the characters admit themselves.

Patient Logs. File bins adjacent to each Recovery Room door contain written observations regarding each patient. Most of the information is mundane: name, diagnosis, chief complaints, and procedures performed. A character who spends 1 minute reading the logs and succeeds on a [[/check INV DC 12]] check deduces that the patients are receiving genuine therapies for physical and mental ailments. Succeeding on this check by 5 or more reveals this is only to prepare them for “further treatment” on the Second Floor.

Secret Entrance. One room (area L11d) is noticeably cooler than the others, containing a hidden hatch beneath a bed leading to the Grotto of Tears. A character who spends 1 minute scouring the room and succeeds on a [[/check PRC DC 18]] or [[/check INV DC 18]] check finds a panel of floor that can be pulled up to reveal a magical stone slab marked with strange carvings.

These are eldritch glyphs from the ancient civilization of eel-like entities that lived in the lake and once worshiped the White Worm, now used by Doctor Belkin to gain easy access to his object of devotion. When the proper incantation is uttered in Deep Speech, the sigils glow violet and the stone depresses, revealing a roughly hewn staircase that leads to the southern tunnel of the Grotto of Tears. This incantation can be learned from Doctor Belkin himself, by studying Belkin's notes in his office (area L23), or by casting @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.3OZnNhunvRtPOQmH]{Identify} on the stone.

L12: Examination Room - First Floor, Con.name: L12: Examination Room - First Floor, Convalescent Ward
L12: Examination Room - First Floor, Con.text:
L12: Examination Room - First Floor, Convalescent Ward

A single overhead lamp illuminates a metal examination table in the center of the room. Cabinets line the walls, their glass doors safeguarding medical tools and bandages.

When needed, Doctor Belkin (@UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.aHAfPdP24eevOUSO]{Wormhost Surgeon}*) takes the Elevator (area L6b) down from the Second Floor to provide medical exams to any who seek them out. Before he enters, he consumes a Potion of Mind Reading to better assess new potential candidates. He uses @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.ppWAAEul0QHtm4er]{Detect Thoughts} to learn what is in the mind of his subjects but does not probe deep enough to trigger a Wisdom saving throw so as not to raise suspicion.

A gaunt figure enters the room wearing a blood-streaked smock and protective coverings on his hands and head. His eyes, visible between the scrub cap and fabric mask, stare out with detached curiosity. He folds his hands together and rasps, “Apologies for the mess. My name is Doctor Belkin, and I am pleased to assist with your health assessment.”

Medical Assessment. Belkin performs a quick medical examination, speaking in a stately, academic tone. Using hints that he gathers from the surface thoughts of each character, he asks fitting questions. A few queries and their resulting prescription (see below) include:

  • “Do you feel your strength waning?” (Tonic)

  • “Do you find it difficult to quiet your thoughts? Perhaps trouble sleeping?” (Sedative)

  • “Have you struggled with interpersonal interactions lately? Do you ever feel out of place?” (Hypnotic)

  • “Have you experienced any tension in your muscles or unexplained fatigue?” (Relaxant)

  • “Do you ever feel overwhelmed by your own thoughts or abilities?” (Suppressant)

  • “Are you often weighed down by melancholy or negative thoughts?” (Euphoriant)

When each assessment is completed, Belkin offers characters with fewer than their maximum hit points a restorative, gesturing to one of a half-dozen syringes resting on a nearby tray. “It is perfectly safe and quite effective.” As an action, the injection restores [[/damage 2d4+2 healing]]{2d4 + 2 hit points}, grants an equal number of temporary hit points, and makes the character slightly lightheaded (disadvantage on Wisdom checks for [[/r 1d4]] hours).

Based on the characters’ responses, Belkin provides a prescription, instructing them to head to the Pharmacy (area L8) for further treatment. He returns to the Second Floor to continue his experiments when the examinations are completed.

L13: Operating Theater - First Floor, Co.name: L13: Operating Theater - First Floor, Convalescent Ward
L13: Operating Theater - First Floor, Co.text:
L13: Operating Theater - First Floor, Convalescent Ward

“The operating theater can seat up to twenty-four observers. Two sets of stairs rise to the raked seats surrounding a bright central pit. A pair of physicians watch in silent curiosity as the operating surgeon performs their work on an unconscious patient, narrating their technique as they progress.

When the characters arrive, a @UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.aHAfPdP24eevOUSO]{Wormhost Surgeon}* operates on an unconscious patient (neutral, human @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.SqZRuJ8lt2KGJBbq]{Commoner} with 8 hit points) on the surgical table in the center of the room, their veins pulsing a strange violet color. Two additional wormhost surgeons sit in the stands. All three surgeons have caps and smocks that cover their mutations and modifications. The characters are invited to stay to observe the surgery.

Medical Emergency. The demonstrated operation begins successfully, albeit gruesomely, with the surgeons opening up the patient’s abdomen to remove a pulsing purple growth. However, the surgery quickly goes wrong as the patient convulses and rapidly mutates, their skin turning pallid violet as a foot and an arm turn wormlike.

The patient lurches from the operating table and attacks the surgeons, who feign helplessness to not reveal their true form and power. This mutated patient uses @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.Hm4o2FgPZsdbXjLq]{Flesh Golem} statistics but is an Aberration, has 50 hit points, lacks the Lightning Absorption feature, and its Slam attacks deal an extra [[/damage 1d4 psychic]] damage.

If the characters kill the patient or knock them out, the surgeons apologize for the mishap and wheel them to the elevator to be added to Doctor Belkin’s experimental amalgam in the Experiment Lab (area L26). If the characters leave the Operating Theater without dealing with the mutated patient, the surgeons subdue the patient and take them to Monster Containment (area L22).

Second Floor.name: Second Floor
Second Floor.text:
Second Floor

The Second Floor of Memory’s Rest veils the truth of Matron Lethica’s work from the world, where suffering and horrific mutations are ignored in the name of “healing.” Like the First Floor, it is divided into two wings: a Processing Wing where the Lethic Serum is tested and an Experimental Wing where those who survive its effects are contained and observed. The entire Second Floor is a Restricted area.

Second Floor Locations

The following areas are keyed to map 17.2.

L14: Orderlies’ Apartments - Second Floo.name: L14: Orderlies’ Apartments - Second Floor, Processing Wing
L14: Orderlies’ Apartments - Second Floo.text:
L14: Orderlies’ Apartments - Second Floor, Processing Wing

The orderlies’ apartments are cramped with narrow cots covered in thin blankets. There are no decorations, save for several full-length wall mirrors.

Each apartment houses a single @UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.wYDQmBRsrRo8AAta]{Mutant Nurse}* at a given time. They sit or stand idly until called to their duties or disturbed by intruders. Characters can sneak through the corridor past the orderlies with a successful [[/check STE DC 17]] check. If alerted, they are hostile toward anyone on the Second Floor who isn’t being escorted by a staff member and will attempt to subdue any intruders with Lethic Serum.

L15: Restraining Room - Second Floor, Pr.name: L15: Restraining Room - Second Floor, Processing Wing
L15: Restraining Room - Second Floor, Pr.text:
L15: Restraining Room - Second Floor, Processing Wing

A heavy metal chair with thick leather straps is bolted firmly to the floor of this room. Restraints, nearly wrenched from their iron sockets, dangle ominously. Tables and shelves holding scalpels, rusted calipers, and a sinister-looking corkscrew-shaped tool surround the table.

You can hear the ragged breathing of the patient bound to the chair, their veins faintly glowing violet. They slump in the chair, barely conscious, their head lolling to one side. Their voice, hoarse with strain, cracks the stillness, “Please… stop…”

Serum-Induced Mutation. The patient strapped to the chair is undergoing the effects of a second dose of Lethic Serum (see “The Lethic Serum” earlier in this chapter) and has been left alone and restrained until the transformation is complete. They react to the presence of other creatures in the room. “H-help me... it’s in me... burning...!” Their shouting threatens to attract attention from nearby staff unless they are quickly calmed or left alone. If calmed, the patient explains they have no recollection of who they are.

Nearby, a handwritten log reads:

Godlee—Administered second dose of Lethic Serum. This new compound promises to produce more stable results, but we must be patient to learn its outcome. Heightened emotional states may affect the results. Leave them here alone.

Sidenote—the ash in the cremator has begun to exhibit unusual properties. It resists dispersal, almost as though it retains a memory of the forms it once composed. I suspect the residue may be a result of traces of the serum in the bodies. Collect samples for further study.

A character who examines the patient and succeeds on a [[/check MED DC 13]] or [[/check ARC DC 13]] check learns exactly how much time remains before the patient transforms. The patient has [[/r 1d4]] hours remaining. Only the antidote to the Lethic Serum (see “The Solution” earlier in this chapter), a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.3okM6Gn63zzEULkz]{Wish} spell, or the patient’s death can halt the transformation.

L16: Sedation Hall - Second Floor, Proce.name: L16: Sedation Hall - Second Floor, Processing Wing
L16: Sedation Hall - Second Floor, Proce.text:
L16: Sedation Hall - Second Floor, Processing Wing

Beds in stark hospital-white sheets line the walls of this wide, pale gray room. Deathly-still patients in hospital gowns breathe shallowly in each bed, separated only by thin curtains. They don’t seem to mind the lack of privacy.

Patients. Three of the twelve beds in this room are occupied by a patient (neutral, human noncombatant @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.SqZRuJ8lt2KGJBbq]{Commoners}). All patients here are suffering the immediate effects of the Lethic Serum and are stunned until the effects wear off (see “The Lethic Serum” earlier in this chapter). While in this condition, they can only move their heads, their eyes don’t focus, and their speech is languid and slurred. They have no desires, no memory of their past, and are perfectly tranquil. They do not resist being moved.

Waking the Afflicted. Not all the patients receive the Lethic Serum at the same time. They are kept in this state until they are ready to be moved back to the First Floor or the next trial is ready (see area L26, Experiment Lab). A successful [[/check MED DC 12]] check determines if a patient is nearing the end of their sedation and can be woken without requiring @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.F0GsG0SJzsIOacwV]{Lesser Restoration} or similar magic, at your discretion.

Roll [[/r 1d6]] if a patient is woken. On a roll of 1 or 2, the patient jerks back into consciousness and begins screaming for help, feebly attacking the characters before they realize what is happening. If the nearby orderlies are not alerted by screaming, the patient can share what they can recall in hushed whispers.

All woken patients understand the danger they are in and wish to leave as soon as possible, though they remain in poor condition from the effects of the Lethic Serum.

L17: Godlee’s Quarters - Second Floor, P.name: L17: Godlee’s Quarters - Second Floor, Processing Wing
L17: Godlee’s Quarters - Second Floor, P.text:
L17: Godlee’s Quarters - Second Floor, Processing Wing

The room is impeccably ordered. Every item is placed deliberately. A narrow desk holds stacked ledgers beside a vase of tidy black irises. A compact bed occupies the corner, its linens tucked with military precision.

Nurse Sarah Godlee (@UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.wYDQmBRsrRo8AAta]{Mutant Nurse}*) lives here in comfort, sleeping on a soft mattress with fine linen sheets. She refreshes her vase of irises every Twilight Hour while reviewing and updating her comprehensive patient registry, which is used as the master ledger in the sanatorium.

If Nurse Godlee sees the characters as useful for attempting to pull Matron Lethica out of her decades-long grief over her lost husband, she’ll bring the characters here to speak in private (see “Sarah Godlee and the Orderlies” earlier in this chapter). A character can earn her trust with a successful [[/check DEC DC 17]] or [[/check PER DC 17]] check.

If they do, she’ll discreetly instruct the orderlies to look the other way as the characters explore the sanatorium. She also confides that Lethica is easily pained when confronted by mementos of her past, which can be found in Lethica’s Quarters (area L19), wishing for them to be destroyed so they no longer torture her employer.

Treasure. A successful [[/check PRC DC 14]] or [[/check INV DC 14]] check while searching the room uncovers Godlee’s stash of valuables hidden beneath her bed:

  • A @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.SqTtbBCfiEsmZ36N]{Bead of Force}

  • A @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.1taRIMF9w7jpnonN]{Wand of Magic Missiles}

  • A tarnished brass @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.LC5LsQOPwoHQW9Mi]{Ring of Water Walking}

  • A @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.Qy2aRjl4iQ8EmaT5]{diplomat's pack}

  • A variety of elegant jewelry totaling [[/award 250gp]]

  • A small diary showcasing Godlee’s admiration for and obsession with Matron Lethica, revealing that the way to enter her personal Laboratory (area L27) is to inject a dose of Lethic Serum into the eye of the owl painted on the wall of the second floor hallway.

L18: Crematorium - Second Floor, Process.name: L18: Crematorium - Second Floor, Processing Wing
L18: Crematorium - Second Floor, Process.text:
L18: Crematorium - Second Floor, Processing Wing

Pushing through the doors, you are hit with the scent of smoke and charred remains. One side of this room houses two massive cremators, their brick interiors blackened from frequent use. Opposite, an array of square-doored lockers line the wall.

Morgue Cabinets. Each of the twelve cabinets contains a corpse in various stages of decay, many with telltale signs of Lethic Serum’s influence. Each body burned in the cremator (which takes 3 hours) produces enough Mnemonic Residue to craft 1 dose of antidote solution (see “The Solution” earlier in this chapter). A character who searches the lockers and succeeds on a [[/check PRC DC 14]] check finds a ward key that was forgotten on the chest of a corpse.

Rekindled Recollections. The gray ashes within the furnace of the cremator glint with specks of purple. This is Mnemonic Residue, enough to produce 3 antidotes.

To collect the residue, a character can use an appropriate set of tools (such as a spoon from cook’s utensils) to scoop the delicate powder into a container.

L19: Lethica’s Quarters - Second Floor.name: L19: Lethica’s Quarters - Second Floor
L19: Lethica’s Quarters - Second Floor.text:
L19: Lethica’s Quarters - Second Floor

A large desk occupies one side of this room, its surface covered with alchemical notes and diagrams. The sparse furnishings suggest a place of work rather than welcome, with no chairs for visitors and shelves lined with neatly ordered books.

Beyond a narrow doorway lies a small, practical bedroom decorated in muted hues of grays, blacks, and purples.

@UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.rRPdaWWKHDjQi0II]{The Weeping Widow}* spends much of her time in her chambers when she isn’t working in her Laboratory (area L27) or below the sanatorium (see “Grotto of Tears” later in this chapter).

Serum Diagrams. A character who spends 1 minute examining the diagrams and succeeds on a [[/check ARC DC 12]] check reveals countless revisions of the Lethic Serum and that it is distilled from the ichor of a being Lethica refers to as the White Worm. If they succeed on the check by 5 or more, the character also deduces how to concoct an antidote that cures a Humanoid of all ill effects of the serum (see “The Solution” earlier in this chapter).

Treasured Memories. A shrine in one corner contains melancholic mementos of Lethica’s life before she came to Memory’s Rest:

  • A portrait of Lethica and Marius Renathyr, painted on the night they were wed

  • Her silver-and-purple-garnet betrothal ring—a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.QtmVEreNIWEVOoLR]{Ring of Protection}

  • A blood-stained knight’s tabard bearing heraldry depicting a rising sun

  • A weathered parchment bearing a faded sonnet of undying love

  • A small phial of Unrefined Ichor (see “The Solution” earlier in this chapter)

Fated Tarot Reading. If The High Priestess was pulled during the “Fated Tarot Reading” in chapter 9, the @UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-treasury.Item.pdnVeDtGEY8QpuqK]{Mask of Lethica Nightborne}* can be found among the mementos in the shrine.

L20: Engineering Room - Second Floor.name: L20: Engineering Room - Second Floor
L20: Engineering Room - Second Floor.text:
L20: Engineering Room - Second Floor

The engineering room sprawls with metal pipes and violet-glass conduits that extend across the space, reaching the floor, walls, and ceiling. The room hums softly, while a central cylindrical unit hisses and wheezes. Its surface is a jumble of levers, switches, pressure gauges, and valves.

The Engineering Room powers all of the fluorescent lights that run throughout Memory’s Rest Sanatorium. The central unit maintains the pressure of condensed steam produced from heating the glowing waters of the Grotto of Tears. Unbeknownst even to Lethica, the tubes behave like alchemical receptacles and have been absorbing painful memories for years.

Reset Protocol. When Lockdown is triggered, the pressurized steam within the sanatorium’s bulbs is suddenly released through a vent mounted on the roof which produces a deafening mournful wail like a siren. Violet fog settles over the Isle of Mourn as the sound fades. Restoring light to the sanatorium requires re-engaging the central unit by turning its lever switch to the “ON” position as an action, which refills the tubes with illumination. The system can also be turned off from here by switching the same lever to “OFF,” which triggers Lockdown.

Memory Overflow. Tampering with or breaking the central unit of the Engineering Room makes Lockdown impossible (the steam slowly dissipates over the next 24 hours), but doing so unleashes what has been gestating within; a viscous, violet liquid oozes forth from the machinery to form a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.8pX2JhWUpTNNRBVx]{Gibbering Mouther}. The voices of a thousand horrid memories babble from the gurgling sludge, which lurches forward and attempts to absorb the nearest creature. Roll initiative! On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), and again for [[/r 1d4]] more rounds thereafter, another gibbering mouther appears in the Engineering Room and attacks any creature other than gibbering mouthers it encounters.

L21: Hugo’s Quarters - Second Floor.name: L21: Hugo’s Quarters - Second Floor
L21: Hugo’s Quarters - Second Floor.text:
L21: Hugo’s Quarters - Second Floor

At first, this room feels more like the den of an animal than a living space. Nearly a quarter of the area is covered in a wide unkempt woven mat, surrounded by scattered trays bearing scraps of food and empty bowls. A high shelf on one side is crowded with vials and injectors.

Treasure. 8 feet up from the floor, a hardy shelf supports a line of vials alongside oversized syringes, though only three are full. The vials contain supplementary stabilizer compounds to help Hugo (@UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.mkR54wUHh2EX8eY6]{Serum Brute}*) manage symptoms caused by his alchemical infusions:

  • Numbing Agent (@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.ReMbjfeOKoSj3O79]{Stoneskin})

  • Alkaline Stabilizer (@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.j8NtLXOOJ3GAKF8I]{Protection from Energy}, acid)

  • Adrenal Stimulant (@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.9eOZDBImVKxbeOyZ]{Enhance Ability}, Bear’s Endurance)

As an action or a bonus action, a vial can be loaded into an injector. It can then be injected into a creature with an action to grant it the effect of the corresponding spell (no concentration required), which deals 1d4 piercing damage to the target that can’t be reduced or prevented in any way. Attempting to extract or collect the compounds without using an injector destroys a vial’s contents.

Experimental Procedure File. A character who explores the room and succeeds on a [[/check PRC DC 15]] check notices a yellowing file folder tucked beneath one side of the woven bed. It includes a detailed record of Hugo’s surgeries and transformation (see “Hugo, the First Experiment” earlier in this chapter), including notes describing the nature of his curse and dependency on it.

L22: Monster Containment - Second Floor,.name: L22: Monster Containment - Second Floor, Experimental Wing
L22: Monster Containment - Second Floor,.text:
L22: Monster Containment - Second Floor, Experimental Wing

A reinforced glass chamber occupies the center of the room, its walls fogged with condensation. Against a far wall, rows of oversized jars contain floating brains suspended in luminescent fluid. Below the jars is a sign that reads: “Do not disturb.” A curtain at the back of the chamber runs the full length of the room, mounted on tracks that allow it to slide open.

Don’t Tap the Glass. The reinforced glass chamber holds a fleshy abomination (use @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.jcZblJ6lqtW0ePxe]{Otyugh} stat block), its misshapen form blurred through the condensation, pacing in restless agitation. It occasionally presses its body against the glass as if testing the containment. A large, empty sipper bottle hangs from the top of the chamber, its nozzle bent and stained with a fluorescent violet residue. A small panel set into the wall beside the chamber holds the mechanism for opening the glass door. The smaller cages concealed by the curtain are empty.

Abnormal Brains. The brains within these jars once belonged to particularly intelligent patients. Doctor Belkin discovered that if he removed the brains of those patients and siphoned the thoughts of their active minds, he was able to collect a pale concentrate, called Noetic Extract, which he uses to nourish horrors like the one in the containment chamber. It is also a key component in producing an antidote to the Lethic Serum (see “The Solution” earlier in this chapter).

Each active brain jar produces enough Noetic Extract for 1 dose of the antidote solution in a 24-hour period. These are automatically collected and dispensed in sealed vials by the mechanisms at the base of each jar. 1d6 vials of Noetic Extract are ready to be extracted when the characters arrive.

L23: Belkin’s Office - Second Floor, Exp.name: L23: Belkin’s Office - Second Floor, Experimental Wing
L23: Belkin’s Office - Second Floor, Exp.text:
L23: Belkin’s Office - Second Floor, Experimental Wing

Shelves line the walls, crowded with preservation vessels containing specimens suspended in cloudy fluid. A high-backed chair stands behind a broad steel desk, its surface a chaos of open journals, anatomical sketches, and surgical diagrams.

Doctor Belkin (@UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.aHAfPdP24eevOUSO]{Wormhost Surgeon}*) spends his time here when not experimenting or performing surgeries.

Dormant Larvae. A jar of parasitic worms suspended in fluid rests on the desk. They awaken and attack any nearby living creature if the jar is opened or broken (use the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.XfQMBoTh892XSnCX]{Swarm of Poisonous Snakes} stat block, dealing psychic damage instead of poison).

Anatomist’s Journal. A character who spends 1 minute studying Belkin’s notes and succeeds on a DC 14 Intelligence (Arcana) or Wisdom (Medicine) check uncovers the following:

A log entry describing Belkin’s frustration that he has been unable to quell the experiments’ (@UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.NJYWcanCwV0B8ddx]{Hospital Horrors}*) fear of needles and other sharp implements

A sketch of the Grotto of Tears, including the White Worm suspended with chains and tubes.

Exploration logs of the caverns beneath the hospital and the ancient ruins found within, noting that Matron Lethica herself first showed him the secrets of the White Worm there (see “Eater of Memory” earlier in this chapter)

A sketch of an eel-like entity—noted to have been the species of the ruined civilization that first worshiped the White Worm—and attempts to decipher their language

The incantation to activate the sigils that opens the secret passage to the Grotto of Tears from one of the Recovery Rooms (area L11d). Characters who can speak Deep Speech can commit it to memory by spending 1 minute reading it. Otherwise, a character must succeed on a [[/check ARC DC 17]] or [[/check HIS DC 17]] check to learn it.

L24: Surgeons’ Rooms - Second Floor, Exp.name: L24: Surgeons’ Rooms - Second Floor, Experimental Wing
L24: Surgeons’ Rooms - Second Floor, Exp.text:
L24: Surgeons’ Rooms - Second Floor, Experimental Wing

This cramped room is unsettlingly damp and completely unlit. Large, metal pods line every wall, each one slick with a slimy sheen that has a faint, violet hue.

There are six pods total in the room, three of which are occupied by sleeping @UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.aHAfPdP24eevOUSO]{Wormhost Surgeons}*. They wake up if disturbed by a loud noise or additional source of light.

Vision of the White Worm. Roll [[/r 1d4]] if an unoccupied pod is searched. On a 1, parasitic worms spill free from the pod and attack any creature that is not a surgeon (use the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.XfQMBoTh892XSnCX]{Swarm of Poisonous Snakes} stat block, which deals psychic damage instead of poison). A creature that searches a pod comes in contact with the gel that coats its interior, and for 10 minutes, the creature can also see through the many eyes of the White Worm in the Grotto of Tears below, as per the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.cg50KpBkBdPK6vPL]{Clairvoyance} spell (no concentration required, sight only).

L25: Observation Chambers - Second Floor.name: L25: Observation Chambers - Second Floor, Experimental Wing
L25: Observation Chambers - Second Floor.text:
L25: Observation Chambers - Second Floor, Experimental Wing

Two glass-walled chambers stand side by side, their interiors stark and sterile. The first chamber is empty save for a single chair bolted to the tiled floor, gleaming under the violet glow of the tubes overhead. The second chamber’s chair is empty, but a patient cowers in the far corner of the room.

Both doors to the chamber are locked, and the walls and doors facing the corridor are reinforced glass.

Chamber One. A character who examines the chamber finds scratches etched into the floor tiles. The markings form a crude warning: “It hungers for memory.”

Chamber Two. The cowering patient (neutral, human noncombatant @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.SqZRuJ8lt2KGJBbq]{Commoner}) is at the precipice of transformation into a @UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.aHAfPdP24eevOUSO]{Wormhost Surgeon}*; their exposed brain is visibly agitated with parasitic worms. For the next [[/r 1d8]] hours, the patient is stunned and their speed is 0, after which the transformation completes. When another creature enters the chamber, the patient babbles incoherently, accelerating the transformation to 10 minutes.

A successful [[/check MED DC 15]] check reveals that the parasitic worms can be destroyed without harming the patient by dealing psychic damage (10 hit points, with a damage threshold of 10) or drawn out by injecting Lethic Serum (which also destroys the worms).

If saved, the patient has no recollection of who they once were, but they remembers being selected for this transformation after inadvertently seeing Doctor Belkin use a hidden passage in one of the Recovery Rooms (area L11d).

L26: Experiment Lab - Second Floor, Expe.name: L26: Experiment Lab - Second Floor, Experimental Wing
L26: Experiment Lab - Second Floor, Expe.text:
L26: Experiment Lab - Second Floor, Experimental Wing

A heavy metal door conceals a haphazard workshop that reeks of antiseptic and charred flesh. Bloodied instruments and organ jars clutter every surface. At the center of the room, an operating table is shrouded by a stained linen sheet that is malformed by the mass beneath it.

If Doctor Belkin (@UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.aHAfPdP24eevOUSO]{Wormhost Surgeon}*) is present when the characters enter, he is hunched over a glowing jar on one desk. It contains a unique blend of writhing alien tissues and serums that exhibit properties that fascinate Belkin.

Belkin doesn’t immediately consider the characters a threat and is indifferent toward them. Unless he knows they have endangered his experiments or if Lockdown is in effect, he sees their arrival as an opportunity.

The Experiment. Doctor Belkin is preparing to conduct an experiment to produce his finest creation yet, which he hopes will serve as the next stage of evolution to be closer in nature to the White Worm. The abomination, a fused amalgam of former mutated patients, is concealed beneath a sheet on the operating table. He believes that the characters would serve as an ideal first combat test for this creature—and a satisfactory meal should the abomination destroy them.

Belkin’s Offer. Belkin is always in search of new pupils and worshipers of the White Worm. Before unleashing his experiment, he offers them the chance to see truth beyond the reality of Druskenvald and witness the perfection of form. Characters who accept can undergo a 1 hour procedure that transforms them into a @UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.aHAfPdP24eevOUSO]{Wormhost Surgeon}*.

The Creation Rises. If any characters refuse the offer, attack the doctor, or speak ill of the White Worm, Doctor Belkin flips the switch to bring his horrific creation to life, which attacks the characters until it is destroyed. This vile amalgam of mutant and alien flesh uses the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.kr6r8bhSehACPfZ8]{Chimera} stat block, but it is an Aberration and its Fire Breath deals psychic damage. Belkin chooses to simply observe, but he joins the battle if attacked or when the creature is reduced to half its hit points or fewer.

Undulating Tissue. If the contents of the glowing jar that Doctor Belkin was studying is released, it morphs into a @UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.oVJEqyGVwzL0AldU]{Nameless Thing}* familiar and immediately bonds with the first creature that speaks after it emerges.

Treasure. A successful [[/check PRC DC 15]] check reveals the following items tucked away in corners and cabinets:

  • A canister labelled “pheromones” (a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.63nb14yQRJMc4bIn]{Philter of Love})

  • Four @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.L887NdWEP5NqHCrQ]{Potions of Healing} (greater)

  • A sealed vial of Lethic Serum

L27: Laboratory - Second Floor, Experime.name: L27: Laboratory - Second Floor, Experimental Wing
L27: Laboratory - Second Floor, Experime.text:
L27: Laboratory - Second Floor, Experimental Wing

Both entrances to the Laboratory are concealed behind smooth walls, each bearing a mural depicting a barn owl roosting in a weeping willow. A character who examines one of the murals and succeeds on a [[/check INV DC 16]] or [[/check PRC DC 16]] check spies that one of the owl’s eyes has a small hole cut into the wall, ringed in metal. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, the character notes traces of dried purple fluid (Lethic Serum).

To enter the Laboratory, a full dose of Lethic Serum must be injected into this eye, causing the wall itself to move back on a mechanical arm, revealing the lab beyond. Only Matron Lethica and Nurse Godlee know this fact.

When the characters enter the Laboratory, read or paraphrase the following:

You enter an alchemical laboratory and are met with a symphony of bubbling, dripping, and hissing. Everywhere you turn, an arcane apparatus can be found: Glass vials filled with glowing liquids twist into each other. Rows of stoppered flasks shimmer near flickering gas flames. A lattice of brass tubing snakes across the ceiling, feeding into various tanks and reservoirs.

A window runs the length of the far wall, offering a partial view of the inner courtyard below. Facing the window is a broad elevator platform, constructed from sturdy metal beams and reinforced wood slats.

Alchemical Chaos. The lab is crowded with workbenches, each covered in an assortment of alchemical experiments and processes. Only Lethica knows how to find exactly what she is looking for in this disorganized space. For each minute spent searching the Laboratory, an item is found as determined by the Laboratory Item table, with a maximum of ten items that can be found.

@UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-rollable-tables.RollTable.rAF7incgOghHwNjg]{Laboratory Item}

A character looking for a specific item can also make a [[/check INV DC 16]] or [[/check PRC DC 16]] check to try and find it within the clutter.

Distilled Memory. Dozens of crystal decanters containing glowing, violet-colored liquid can be found scattered throughout the Laboratory—Unrefined Ichor, harvested directly from the White Worm. Each container is labeled with a date and batch number. The substance is a key component in the antidote solution (see “The Solution” earlier in this chapter).

Plunge Platform. The elevator platform on one side of the Laboratory descends to the Grotto of Tears 150 feet below. A lever to activate the lift juts out from the floor adjacent the platform. The descent takes 5 minutes, during which the platform creaks and groans. The shaft is pitch dark, with walls slick from the moisture of the waters below.

The Widow’s Wile. In the corner of the Laboratory stands a mesmerizing orb of glass cradled on a pedestal, its surface alive with arcs of purple lightning. A creature that touches the orb experiences no ill effect and finds the orb cannot be moved. A character who succeeds on a [[/check INV DC 16]] or [[/check PRC DC 16]] check notices a subtle foot lever at the bottom of the pedestal. When the foot lever is pressed, all creatures within the Laboratory not touching the orb are immediately teleported to the Grotto of Tears (see below).

If Matron Lethica (@UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.rRPdaWWKHDjQi0II]{The Weeping Widow}*) finds intruders in her Laboratory, she triggers this device the moment she deems them threatening. Once she has sent them below, she retrieves Hugo (@UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.mkR54wUHh2EX8eY6]{Serum Brute}*) and patiently rides the elevator platform down to face them herself.

The Grotto of Tears.name: The Grotto of Tears
The Grotto of Tears.text:
The Grotto of Tears

Read or paraphrase the following if the characters arrived by means of the “Widow’s Wile” device (area L27), and then read the subsequent description:

Your vision suddenly blurs. The laboratory dissolves around you as if pulled apart by unseen hands. A rushing sensation fills your ears before clarity returns. You now stand on uneven stone, surrounded by the cold glow of an unfamiliar cavern.

Only read the following if the characters reach the Grotto of Tears by elevator lift or secret passage:

An indescribable smell fills this grotto that defies the laws of nature, its stone walls ridged and folded like brain matter. A narrow stone bridge extends across the bubbling, phosphorescent waters of subterranean pools, leading to a circular platform glowing in an otherworldly violet hue.

Above the platform hangs an enormous alien creature that can only be described as a pallid, bloated grub suspended by metal chains. Numerous tubes run from its punctured flesh to vats that line the cavern, pumping a grotesque violet substance that oozes unlike any known in the natural world. Globs of this eldritch gore drips onto the stone below.

This chamber is the torturous home of @UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.6rBNaLaLnzUxIFnE]{The White Worm}*, a being of unknowable power (see “Eater of Memory” earlier in this chapter). In this weakened state, it can take no actions or reactions, and its speed is 0. Matron Lethica’s intense, alien psychic bond with the worm protects the lifeform and its restraints from all damage. If attacked or engaged, it lets out a piercing shriek that alerts Lethica to the presence of intruders.

Grotto of Tears Features

Unless otherwise stated, the grotto has the following features:

Blood of the Worm. The violet fluid dripping from the punctured worm is Unrefined Ichor, a key component in the antidote solution (see “The Solution” earlier in this chapter).

Ceilings and Walls. The cavern ceiling is 40 feet high. The walls of the cavern are natural stone worn to evoke wrinkled gray matter.

Lighting. Water in this area glows an ethereal, almost fluorescent purple, flooding the area with bright light.

Mutation Tanks. The most horrifically mutated patients are kept in glass tanks of highly distilled Lethic Serum after undergoing agonizing body modification to turn each of them into a @UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.NJYWcanCwV0B8ddx]{Hospital Horror}*. These enhanced killers can be released by Matron Lethica to aid her in combat (see “The Chemical Evolution” later in this chapter).

Plunge Platform. A lever in the room’s northern chamber activates the elevator to the Laboratory (area L27). The elevator takes 5 minutes to ascend.

Serum Fermentation Vats. A series of 10-foot-tall, verdigrised copper vats line the walls and are filled with worm organs, blood, tissue, and chemicals. Spidery lengths of copper pipe connect them to distillation boxes, and run into the waters of the grotto. A character who succeeds on a [[/check ARC DC 18]], [[/check INV DC 18]] or [[/check NAT DC 18]] check can deduce that Matron Lethica is seeking to poison the valley’s water supply with Lethic Serum. These vats are highly pressurized and can be used in combat (see “The Chemical Evolution” later in this chapter).

The Chemical Evolution.name: The Chemical Evolution
The Chemical Evolution.text:
The Chemical Evolution

This section assumes the characters confront @UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.rRPdaWWKHDjQi0II]{The Weeping Widow}* in the Grotto of Tears (map 17.3).

If Lethica or Hugo are missing any hit points at the start of this encounter, they are restored to full hit points now. If Hugo was killed earlier during this adventure but not destroyed, he joins Lethica here now, revived by her alchemy.

The White Worm’s Influence

On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the White Worm unleashes one of the following psionic effects; the worm can’t use the same option two rounds in a row:

Homeostasis. One condition or spell of up to 3rd level affecting Lethica ends.

Metabolic Reconstruction. Lethica gains [[/damage 10 temp]].

Psionic Guidance. Lethica has advantage on attack rolls until initiative count 20 on the following round.

Phase 1: First Incision.name: Phase 1: First Incision
Phase 1: First Incision.text:
Phase 1: First Incision

When Matron Lethica ambushes—or is ambushed by—the characters, read or paraphrase the following:

The Weeping Widow stands beside her hulking ward and quickly loads her syringe.

“You threaten my work. You would put a stop to bringing peaceful bliss to all of Wickermoor Hollow. Enough. You are beyond saving… Hugo. Send these fools into oblivion.”

Matron Lethica (@UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.rRPdaWWKHDjQi0II]{The Weeping Widow}*) fights with all her cunning to annihilate her enemies. She and Hugo (@UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.mkR54wUHh2EX8eY6]{Serum Brute}*) act on the same initiative. At the beginning of combat, Lethica injects Hugo with a serum that increases his size to Huge for 24 hours, then Hugo picks her up and places her on his back. She firmly grips his chain leash throughout the fight.

Under Pressure. Spaces occupied by pipes and vats are difficult terrain. A creature in the same space as a pipe or a vat gains two effects:

  • It has half cover.

  • If an attack against the creature misses, the attack targets the pipe or vat instead.

If a copper pipe or vat (AC 13; 10 hit points; immunity to poison and psychic damage) is destroyed, scalding steam and liquid sprays out. Creatures within a 10-foot radius originating from the broken pipe or vat must make a [[/save DEX DC 13]] saving throw, taking [[/damage 4d6 acid]]{14 (4d6)} acid damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. Additionally, the area within the radius is heavily obscured with steam for 1 minute, or until dispersed by a strong wind.

Phase 2: Desperate Measures.name: Phase 2: Desperate Measures
Phase 2: Desperate Measures.text:
Phase 2: Desperate Measures

When Lethica is reduced to half her hit points or fewer, she despairs and becomes willing to sacrifice her designs to survive. She commands the three @UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-bestiary.Actor.NJYWcanCwV0B8ddx]{Hospital Horrors}* to burst free from their mutation tanks and come to her aid. They act on initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties) and attack foes farthest from Lethica.

On her turn, if Hugo has not been reduced to half his hit points or fewer, Lethica pulls at the leash that tethers her to Hugo, which opens his cursed eyes to the world and activates his Unleashed Eyes trait.

Into Oblivion

When Matron Lethica is reduced to 0 hit points, read or paraphrase the following:

Matron Lethica lets out a shuddering wail as thick, black tears run down her face. Her composure breaks, and in her final moments, the widow truly weeps. Her frail form collapses as her violet blood pools beneath her.

A piercing, alien shriek fills the space as the grotto rumbles and the enormous white worm overhead strains against its restraints. With a creaking and crashing, the chains break from the stone, and the colossal creature plunges into the fluorescent waters below, disappearing from sight with supernatural speed.

Alien Unchained. With Lethica’s psychic connection to the worm now broken, its reality-bending restraints shatter, and it escapes to the depths of Moonsong Lake to recover from its torture and imprisonment, gaining in strength until it must feed once more (see chapter 26).

Hugo’s Redemption. If Hugo still lives, he seeks immediate vengeance against those that destroyed Lethica. His veins pump with alchemical compounds and the sudden grief of losing his matron, but he can still be saved. As an action, a character can attempt to calm Hugo and must make a [[/check PER DC 20]] check (with advantage if they deal no damage to Hugo on their turn). On a success, Hugo begins to calm, and the DC for subsequent checks is reduced by 3. After three successful checks, Hugo becomes indifferent and breaks down into a sobbing mass of profound grief.

Level Up. The characters reach 8th level, if they are still 7th level, when they defeat Matron Lethica.

Fated Tarot Reading. If Temperance was pulled during the “Fated Tarot Reading” in chapter 9, the @UUID[Compendium.the-crooked-moon-2014.tcm2014-treasury.Item.Shl4tMLgrC2T1FyV]{Veil of the Weeping Widow}* can be pulled off the cold, lifeless face of Matron Lethica.

Conclusion: Unforgettable Horrors.name: Conclusion: Unforgettable Horrors
Conclusion: Unforgettable Horrors.text:
Conclusion:
Unforgettable Horrors

Killing Matron Lethica puts an end to her vile experiments for good. Her absence, however, leaves Memory’s Rest Sanatorium poised on a fragile edge.

The Widow’s Wake

Without the presence of Matron Lethica, Nurse Godlee (if she lives) is devastated, but still craves control over all who remain. However, she quickly runs out of Lethic Serum and doesn’t know how to brew more. She soon leaves with any living orderlies that still obey her orders, scheming to rebuild her influence.

If Doctor Belkin lives, he becomes obsessed with the White Worm’s secrets and refuses to leave the Isle of Mourn. If forced to leave the sanatorium, he escapes with the surgeons to the caves below—leaving no trace of his work—and seeks the White Worm’s lair deep within Moonsong Lake.

The surviving patients are left in a delicate condition, their minds dulled by the serum. The characters are free to restore and rescue the living inmates of Memory’s Rest Sanatorium and return to Wickermoor Village.

Back in Wickermoor Village

The people of Wickermoor Village rejoice if any former patients return, especially Amos Dority if his cousin is saved. Families pitch in and pay the characters [[/award 25gp]] for each patient they saved, and if the characters devised a cure for those that lost their memories from the Lethic Serum, Mayor Wendel Somerton rewards the characters with an heirloom @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.iiQxTvDOhPGW5spF]{Amulet of Health} that takes the form of an emerald oak leaf.

Without the White Worm producing more Unrefined Ichor, the number of doses of antidote that can be crafted is limited by what remains of its key components in the sanatorium. Put together, there are fewer doses of antidote than there are those whose memories were stolen by the Lethic Serum (including any orderlies that receive the treatment), leaving the difficult choice of who may be saved in the hands of those who know how to procure and produce the solution.

Optionally, you may determine that Morgan the apothecary can produce an alternative cure with the serum diagrams and alternative alchemical ingredients, producing 1 dose after 8 hours of work.

Chapter 21: Fool's Day.name: Chapter 21: Fool's Day
Chapter 21: Fool's Day.description:
“I scream! You scream! We all scream in the fires of the Horned King’s return! They always say that anyone who would be king for a day is a fool for a lifetime, but what’s so bad about being a fool?! Everyone should be a fool for a day at least once in their miserable lives!”

- Chuckles, the Lord of Fools -

What joy there is when a clown comes to town! Though Wickermoor Hollow is draped in shadow and fear, the lights of the Fool’s Day Festival pierce the gloom. Of all the celebrations in Wickermoor Village, none is more cherished—rife with costumed revelers, dancing bears, grand feasts, and lamplight dances.

Chapter Background

Ignore the sinister fact that people vanish each festival night. Fix your gaze on the brilliant, many-colored lanterns and the ever-grinning Chuckles the Clown! Those cries in the night? Simply howls of delight, nothing more. The Fallen are defeated! The Fool’s Day Festival will be happy. It must be happy. The parade is coming, and you will be so, soooo happy.

Chapter Summary

The Fool’s Day Festival consumes Wickermoor Village, led by Chuckles, Lord of Fools. This wicked clown has a perverse death wish and seeks to goad the characters into slaying him as his own ritual sacrifice. While he brings joy to the townsfolk, Chuckles delights in mocking the characters, belittling their previous exploits, and even attacking villagers they care about, so long as it brings them one step closer to killing him. The characters’ goals are:

  • Play carnival games to earn tickets.

  • Rescue the forced revelers through tickets or combat or by severing their enchantments.

  • Free Phillip and Adela Druskenvald from their forced revelry.

  • Destroy Chuckles, the Lord of Fools.

Before running this chapter, you should review Wickermoor Hollow’s townsfolk (see “Forced Revelers” below) to decide the most compelling NPCs to include in this chapter. Read through the festival events (see “Festival of Fools Locations” below) so you can smoothly run games for the characters. Finally, study the climactic battle, “Parade of Fools,” to fill the encounter with menace and hilarity.

This chapter is designed for four level 10 characters.

Herald of Fools.name: Herald of Fools
Herald of Fools.description:
Herald of Fools

Leader of Fiendish Revels

Habitat: Planar (Lower Planes), Urban

Treasure: Implements

Heralds of fools lead troupes of fiendish revelers in service to the enigmatic Lord of Fools, a clown or jester entity who is a curious mix of levity and cruelty (though always with a sense of irony). The heralds are agile and graceful, every movement a dance, spinning their banner poles in intricate displays that can swiftly turn from entertainment to death.

Secret. Heralds of fools are wonderful dancers, and they must never stop dancing, or they quickly perish.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The herald makes three [[/item Banner Pole]] attacks. It can replace one attack with a use of [[/item Lethal Jape]].

Banner Pole.name: Banner Pole
Banner Pole.description: Melee Attack Roll: [[/attack]] (with Advantage if the target’s Speed is 0), reach 10 ft. Hit: [[/damage average]] damage, and if the target is a Large or smaller creature, the herald can move it to any other unoccupied space within the Banner Pole’s reach.

Lethal Jape.name: Lethal Jape
Lethal Jape.description:
Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 15, a creature the herald can see within 60 feet.

Failure: [[/damage average]] damage, and the target’s Speed is 0 until the end of its next turn.

Success: Half damage only.

Wave The Banner.name: Wave The Banner
Wave The Banner.description:
Trigger: An ally of the herald’s within 60 feet misses with an attack roll or fails a saving throw.

Response: The ally can reroll the d20 and must use the new roll.

Endless Footwork.name: Endless Footwork
Endless Footwork.description: When the herald’s Speed is 0, attack rolls made against it have Advantage, and if its Speed is 0 at the start of its turn, it takes 20 Necrotic damage.

Perfect Grace.name: Perfect Grace
Perfect Grace.description: The herald doesn’t provoke an Opportunity Attack when it leaves an enemy’s reach.

Reveler of Song.name: Reveler of Song
Reveler of Song.description:
Reveler of Song

Fiend of Music and Dance

Habitat: Planar (Lower Planes), Urban

Treasure: Implements

Revelers of song are Fiends of music and abandon who turn their art against their foes in destructive reverberation. The revelers dance and play at nearly all times and are known to fly into a murderous rage if their invitations to join the celebration are spurned. A variety of revelers of song exist, depending on the type of instrument a given reveler plays. Drone revelers play the hurdy gurdy and are surrounded by an accompanying swarm of bees. Drum revelers play drums or cymbals, and the world shakes to their beat. Bell revelers play some variety of bell, chime, or gong, and the ringing overtakes all other sounds.

Secret. Revelers of song can’t accept that any creature is more skilled at an instrument than they are and so can’t refuse a musical challenge.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The reveler makes two [[/item Instrumental Blast]] attacks.

Instrumental Blast.name: Instrumental Blast
Instrumental Blast.description: Melee or Ranged Attack Roll: [[/attack]], reach 5 ft. or range 90 ft. Hit: [[/damage average]] damage.

Infectious Rhythm (Drum Only).name: Infectious Rhythm (Drum Only)
Infectious Rhythm (Drum Only).description:
Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 16, up to two creatures the reveler can see within 30 feet.

Failure: [[/damage average]] damage, and the target is affected by the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.TfRzwEgBHHkCc6Ql]{Irresistible Dance} spell (no Concentration required to maintain the spell).

Success: Half damage only.

Stunning Clangor (Bell Only).name: Stunning Clangor  (Bell Only)
Stunning Clangor (Bell Only).description:
Constitution Saving Throw: DC 16, one creature the reveler can see within 60 feet.

Failure: [[/damage average]] damage, and the target has the &reference[stunned apply=false] condition until the end of the reveler’s next turn.

Success: Half damage only.

Compelled Contest.name: Compelled Contest
Compelled Contest.description: The reveler can’t refuse a contest of skill with Musical Instruments. As an Influence action, a creature can make a Charisma (Performance) check using a Musical Instrument. The reveler must succeed on a Charisma saving throw with a DC equal to the check’s total or take [[/damage average]] damage and have the &reference[stunned apply=false]condition until the end of the creature’s next turn.

Dancing Step.name: Dancing Step
Dancing Step.description: The reveler doesn’t provoke Opportunity Attacks when it leaves an enemy’s reach.

Ensemble Form.name: Ensemble Form
Ensemble Form.description: The reveler takes on a specific form: Drone, Drum, or Bell. The form determines certain traits and actions, as well as the instrument the reveler plays (hurdy gurdy, frame drum, or handbells, respectively).

Droning Swarm (Drone Only).name: Droning Swarm  (Drone Only)
Droning Swarm (Drone Only).description:
A droning swarm of bees surrounds the reveler.

Constitution Saving Throw: DC 16, each creature that ends its turn in a 10-foot Emanation originating from the reveler.

Failure: The target has the &reference[poisoned apply=false] condition until the end of its next turn.

Reveler of Stories.name: Reveler of Stories
Reveler of Stories.description:
Reveler of Stories

Fiend of Legend and Folklore

Habitat: Planar (Lower Planes), Urban

Treasure: Arcana

Timeless stories have inspired countless mortals, and the echoes of those stories in the Lower Planes have spawned fiendish embodiments of those tales—the revelers of stories. These Fiends twist the themes of their tales, turning inspiration into doom. The revelers’ forms and powers change depending on the theme of stories they embody. Great beast revelers of stories rise from tales of terrible monsters. Hero revelers of stories embody the exploits of knights and other mighty heroes. Witch revelers of stories bring to life tales of wicked witches, wizards, and other magicians.

Secret. Revelers of stories exist because of fables, legends, and other tales, and reciting the moral of a story related to the reveler’s theme robs the reveler of its potency.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The reveler makes three [[/item Thrash]] attacks. It can replace one attack with a use of Fabled Assault if available.

Thrash.name: Thrash
Thrash.description: Melee Attack Roll: [[/attack]], reach 10 ft. Hit: [[/damage average]] damage.

Fabled Assault.name: Fabled Assault
Fabled Assault.description:
The reveler uses the option determined by its Storied Form:

  • Consuming Bite (Great Beast Only). Constitution Saving Throw: DC 17, one creature within 5 feet (with Disadvantage if the reveler is grappling the target).

    Failure: 36 ([[/r 8d8]]) Necrotic damage. If the target is Huge or smaller, it has the &reference[grappled apply=false] condition (escape DC 15), and it has the &reference[restrained apply=false] condition until the grapple ends.

    Success: Half damage only.

    Failure or Success: The reveler gains Temporary Hit Points equal to the Necrotic damage taken.

  • Heroic Charge (Hero Only). The reveler moves up to its Speed in a straight line without provoking Opportunity Attacks, and it can move through other creatures without expending extra movement to do so.

    Strength Saving Throw: DC 17, each creature whose space the reveler enters.

    Failure: 26 ([[/r 4d12]]) Force damage, and the target has the &reference[prone apply=false] condition.

    Success: Half damage only.

  • Wicked Storm (Witch Only). Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 17, each creature in a 60-foot Cone.

    Failure: 27 ([[/r 6d8[[) Lightning damage, and the target has the &reference[frightened apply=false] condition. While Frightened in this way, the target’s Speed is 0. A Frightened target repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. After 1 minute, it succeeds automatically.

    Success: Half damage only.

Dramatic Reversal.name: Dramatic Reversal
Dramatic Reversal.description:
Trigger: The reveler is hit by an attack roll.

Response: The reveler adds 4 to its AC against that attack, possibly causing it to miss.

Moral Quandary.name: Moral Quandary
Moral Quandary.description: As a Bonus Action, a creature can recite the moral of a story using the same theme as the reveler’s Storied Form to weaken it for 1 hour. While weakened, the reveler can’t take Reactions, and its AC is reduced by 4.

Storied Form.name: Storied Form
Storied Form.description: The reveler takes on a specific form: Great Beast, Hero, or Witch. The form determines certain traits and the theme of stories the reveler embodies (powerful monsters, brave heroes, or wicked magicians, respectively).

Terror Feeding (Witch Only).name: Terror Feeding (Witch Only)
Terror Feeding (Witch Only).description: If there is at least one creature with the &reference[frightened apply=false] condition within 30 feet of the reveler at the end of its turn, the reveler gains 15 Temporary Hit Points.

The Lord of Fools.name: The Lord of Fools
The Lord of Fools.description:
The Lord of Fools

Fiendish Master of Revels

Habitat: Planar (Lower Planes), Urban

The Lord of Fools is the embodiment of revelry, cherishing amusement at any cost. He most often leads a procession of revelers of song, revelers of stories, and heralds of fools, compelling townsfolk and travelers to join their celebration to the exclusion of all other concerns. Many of these celebrants dance, drink, and make merry until they drop—sometimes dead! The Lord of Fools laughs all the louder and longer at their demise.

Secret. The Lord of Fools thrives on laughter and amusement, so when someone doesn’t react accordingly to one of his japes, he becomes enraged at that creature to the exclusion of others.

The Lord of Fools’ Lair

The Lord of Fools’ lair is the Fool’s Revel carnival.

The region containing the Lord of Fools’ lair is changed by its presence, creating the following effects:

Empty Treats. Within 1 mile of the lair, carnival snack food is abundant even in unlikely places. The food is delicious but offers no sustenance. A creature that eats the food can’t feel the effects of starvation (though they still suffer the effects of going without food) for 24 hours.

Pratfalls. Within 1 mile of the lair, ability checks or saving throws made to avoid being knocked prone have disadvantage.

If the Lord of Fools dies or moves his lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

Spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
Spellcasting.description:
The lord casts one of the following spells, requiring no material components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 19):

At Will: Hideous Laughter, Project Image (appears as a Small Humanoid jester), Vicious Mockery (4d6 Psychic damage)

1/Day Each: Irresistible Dance, Magnificent Mansion

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The lord makes two attacks, using [[/item Ribbon]] or [[/item Joy Buzzer]] in any combination. If the lord has cast Project Image, he can make melee [[/item Joy Buzzer]] attacks from the image’s space.

Ribbon.name: Ribbon
Ribbon.description: Melee Attack Roll: [[/attack]], reach 15 ft. Hit: [[/damage average]] damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it has the &reference[Grappled apply=false] condition (escape DC 15) from one of six ribbons. It has the &reference[Restrained apply=false] condition until the grapple ends.

Joy Buzzer.name: Joy Buzzer
Joy Buzzer.description:
The lord’s Infinite Jest illusion moves to a target within range.

Melee or Ranged Attack Roll: [[/attack]], reach 5 ft. or range 60 ft. Hit: [[/damage average]] damage, and the target can’t take Reactions until the end of the lord’s next turn.

Hit or Miss: The jester vanishes and reappears in the lord’s space.

Exploding Pie.name: Exploding Pie
Exploding Pie.description:
The lord throws a massive pie that explodes in corrosive custard.

Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 18, each creature in a 20-foot-radius Sphere centered on a point the lord can see within 100 feet.

Failure: [[/damage average]] damage, and the target has the &reference[Blinded apply=false] condition until the end of the lord’s next turn.

Success: Half damage only.

Legendary Actions.name: Legendary Actions
Legendary Actions.description: The lord can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature’s turn. The lord regains spent legendary actions at the start of his turn.

Frolic.name: Frolic
Frolic.description: The lord moves up to half his Speed without provoking Opportunity Attacks, during which he can move through other creature’s spaces without expending extra movement to do so. A creature whose space the lord enters takes [[/damage average]] damage. A creature takes this damage only once per turn.

Joke’s on You.name: Joke’s on You
Joke’s on You.description: The lord uses Spellcasting to cast either @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplOttosIrres]{Irresistible Dance} or @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplViciousMoc]{Vicious Mockery}.

Ribbon Dance.name: Ribbon Dance
Ribbon Dance.description:
Strength Saving Throw: DC 18, each creature the lord is grappling.

Failure: [[/damage average]] damage.

Success: Half damage.

Failure or Success: The lord can’t take this action again until the start of its next turn.

Lair Actions.name: Lair Actions
Lair Actions.description: The Lord of Fools’ lair is the Fool’s Revel carnival. The region containing the Lord of Fools’ lair is changed by its presence, creating the following effects: If the Lord of Fools dies or moves his lair elsewhere, these effects end immediately.

Empty Treats.name: Empty Treats
Empty Treats.description: Within 1 mile of the lair, carnival snack food is abundant even in unlikely places. The food is delicious but offers no sustenance. A creature that eats the food can’t feel the effects of starvation (though they still suffer the effects of going without food) for 24 hours.

Pratfalls.name: Pratfalls
Pratfalls.description: Within 1 mile of the lair, ability checks or saving throws made to avoid being knocked &Reference[Prone apply=false] have disadvantage.

Ribbon Step.name: Ribbon Step
Ribbon Step.description: The lord vanishes in a burst of confetti and ribbons and teleports to an unoccupied space he can see within 30 feet.

Bitter Medicine.name: Bitter Medicine
Bitter Medicine.description: As a Bonus Action, a creature can dismiss or belittle the lord’s attempts at humor. If the creature succeeds on a DC 16 Charisma (Deception) check, the lord has Disadvantage on attack rolls against any target other than that creature until the start of the creature’s next turn.

Infinite Jest.name: Infinite Jest
Infinite Jest.description: The lord creates an illusion of a Small Humanoid jester in his space. While he doesn’t have the &reference[Incapacitated apply=false] condition, the lord can move the image up to 60 feet during his turn (no action required). The lord can perceive and speak through this image as if he were in the image’s space. The image is insubstantial, but it can manipulate objects as if it has a Strength of 10.

Legendary Resistance.name: Legendary Resistance
Legendary Resistance.description: If the lord fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

Reactive.name: Reactive
Reactive.description: The lord can take one Reaction on every turn of combat.

Hideous Laughter.name: Hideous Laughter
Hideous Laughter.description:
One creature of your choice that you can see within range makes a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it has the &Reference[prone apply=false] and &Reference[incapacitated apply=false] conditions for the duration. During that time, it laughs uncontrollably if it's capable of laughter, and it can't end the Prone condition on itself.

At the end of each of its turns and each time it takes damage, it makes another [[/save ability=wis dc=@attributes.spell.dc]] saving throw. The target has Advantage on the save if the save is triggered by damage. On a successful save, the spell ends.

Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot. You can target one additional creature for each spell slot level about 1.

Uncontrollable Laughter.name: Uncontrollable Laughter
Uncontrollable Laughter.description:
has the &Reference[prone apply=false] and &Reference[incapacitated apply=false] conditions for the duration. During that time, it laughs uncontrollably if it’s capable of laughter, and it can’t end the Prone condition on itself.

At the end of each of its turns and each time it takes damage, it makes another [[/save ability=wis dc=@attributes.spell.dc]] saving throw. The target has Advantage on the save if the save is triggered by damage. On a successful save, the spell ends.

Project Image.name: Project Image
Project Image.description:
You create an illusory copy of yourself that lasts for the duration. The copy can appear at any location within range that you have seen before, regardless of intervening obstacles. The illusion looks and sounds like you, but it is intangible. If the illusion takes any damage, it disappears, and the spell ends.

You can see through the illusion's eyes and hear through its ears as if you were in its space. As a Magic action, you can move it up to 60 feet and make it gesture, speak, and behave in whatever way you choose. It mimics your mannerisms perfectly.

Physical interaction with the image reveals it to be illusory, since things can pass through it. A creature that takes the Study action to examine the image can determine that it is an illusion with a successful [[/check ability=int skill=inv dc=@attributes.spell.dc]] check against your spell save DC. If a creature discerns the illusion for what it is, the creature can see through the image, and any noise it makes sounds hollow to the creature.

materials.value: a statuette of yourself worth 5+ GP

Vicious Mockery.name: Vicious Mockery
Vicious Mockery.description:
You unleash a string of insults laced with subtle enchantments at one creature you can see or hear within range. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or take 1d6 Psychic damage and have Disadvantage on the next attack roll it makes before the end of its next turn.

Cantrip Upgrade. The damage increases by 1d6 when you reach levels 5 (2d6), 11 (3d6), and 17 (4d6).

Mocked.name: Mocked
Mocked.description: The target has Disadvantage on the next attack roll it makes before the end of its next turn.

Irresistible Dance.name: Irresistible Dance
Irresistible Dance.description:
One creature that you can see within range must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a successful save, the target dances comically until the end of its next turn, during which it must spend all its movement to dance in place.

On a failed save, the target has the Charmed condition for the duration. While Charmed, the target dances comically, must use all its movement to dance in place, and has Disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws and attack rolls, and other creatures have Advantage on attack rolls against it. On each of its turns, the target can take an action to collect itself and repeat the save, ending the spell on itself on a success.

Irresistible Dance.name: Irresistible Dance
Irresistible Dance.description: While &Reference[Charmed apply=false], the target dances comically, must use all its movement to dance in place, and has Disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws and attack rolls, and other creatures have Advantage on attack rolls against it. On each of its turns, the target can take an action to collect itself and repeat the [[/save ability=wis]] save, ending the spell on itself on a success.

Short Dance.name: Short Dance
Short Dance.description: The target dances comically until the end of its next turn, during which it must spend all its movement to dance in place.

Magnificent Mansion.name: Magnificent Mansion
Magnificent Mansion.description:
You conjure a shimmering door in range that lasts for the duration. The door leads to an extradimensional dwelling and is 5 feet wide and 10 feet tall. You and any creature you designate when you cast the spell can enter the extradimensional dwelling as long as the door remains open. You can open or close it (no action required) if you are within 30 feet of it. While closed, the door is imperceptible.

Beyond the door is a magnificent foyer with numerous chambers beyond. The dwelling's atmosphere is clean, fresh, and warm.

You can create any floor plan you like for the dwelling, but it can't exceed 50 contiguous 10-foot Cubes. The place is furnished and decorated as you choose. It contains sufficient food to serve a nine-course banquet for up to 100 people. Furnishings and other objects created by this spell dissipate into smoke if removed from it.

A staff of 100 near-transparent servants attends all who enter. You determine the appearance of these servants and their attire. They are invulnerable and obey your commands. Each servant can perform tasks that a human could perform, but they can't attack or take any action that would directly harm another creature. Thus the servants can fetch things, clean, mend, fold clothes, light fires, serve food, pour wine, and so on. The servants can't leave the dwelling.

When the spell ends, any creatures or objects left inside the extradimensional space are expelled into the unoccupied spaces nearest to the entrance.

Chapter 21: Fool's Day.name: Chapter 21: Fool's Day
Chapter 21: Fool's Day.text:
Chapter 21:

Fool's Day

“I scream! You scream! We all scream in the fires of the Horned King’s return! They always say that anyone who would be king for a day is a fool for a lifetime, but what’s so bad about being a fool?! Everyone should be a fool for a day at least once in their miserable lives!”

- Chuckles, the Lord of Fools -

What joy there is when a clown comes to town! Though Wickermoor Hollow is draped in shadow and fear, the lights of the Fool’s Day Festival pierce the gloom. Of all the celebrations in Wickermoor Village, none is more cherished—rife with costumed revelers, dancing bears, grand feasts, and lamplight dances.

Chapter Background

Ignore the sinister fact that people vanish each festival night. Fix your gaze on the brilliant, many-colored lanterns and the ever-grinning Chuckles the Clown! Those cries in the night? Simply howls of delight, nothing more. The Fallen are defeated! The Fool’s Day Festival will be happy. It must be happy. The parade is coming, and you will be so, soooo happy.

Chapter Summary

The Fool’s Day Festival consumes Wickermoor Village, led by Chuckles, Lord of Fools. This wicked clown has a perverse death wish and seeks to goad the characters into slaying him as his own ritual sacrifice. While he brings joy to the townsfolk, Chuckles delights in mocking the characters, belittling their previous exploits, and even attacking villagers they care about, so long as it brings them one step closer to killing him. The characters’ goals are:

  • Play carnival games to earn tickets.

  • Rescue the forced revelers through tickets or combat or by severing their enchantments.

  • Free Phillip and Adela Druskenvald from their forced revelry.

  • Destroy Chuckles, the Lord of Fools.

Before running this chapter, you should review Wickermoor Hollow’s townsfolk (see “Forced Revelers” below) to decide the most compelling NPCs to include in this chapter. Read through the festival events (see “Festival of Fools Locations” below) so you can smoothly run games for the characters. Finally, study the climactic battle, “Parade of Fools,” to fill the encounter with menace and hilarity.

This chapter is designed for four level 10 characters.

The Lord of Fools.name: The Lord of Fools
The Lord of Fools.text:
The Lord of Fools
