Wickermoor Village looms within reach, but the foreboding silence and encroaching gloom make every step toward it feel like an entry into something… crooked.

Chapter 18: Hartsblight Forest.name: Chapter 18: Hartsblight Forest
Chapter 18: Hartsblight Forest.description:
“Green is the color of life. It is the color of rot. When you see it creep into your towns, you rip it up. When you see it bloom beneath your skin, you bleed it out. But despite your struggle, it always returns. When your cities, your skin, your bones, and your virtue are gone, all that remains will be green.”

- Gorthos, the Beast of Blight -

A creeping rot festers in Wickermoor Hollow. A once-vibrant forest has fallen to a virulent blight that consumes trees, animals, and people alike—threatening to seed all life with rapidly spreading decay. Deep in the heart of the dying woodland, the Beast of Blight nurtures this rot, delivering death laced with the promise of rebirth. Those willing to endure the poisonous reaches of Hartsblight Forest must unearth and purge the source of the blight to put a stop to the spreading menace before it turns all to rot.

Chapter Background

Hartsblight Forest was once a lush and verdant woodland at the edge of Wickermoor Hollow known as the Greenwood, home to a community of antlered, deerlike satyrs that cared for its flora and fauna. Now, it is a rotten place putrefied by Hartsblight, a fungal infection that brings decay to all living things.

The first to surrender to the corruption of the blight was a young satyr named Farryn of the Greenwood, who followed the call of a dead primeval god to the origin of Hartsblight. Driven by the desperation of love, loss, and the hope for rebirth, she embraced the rot and forever changed into a monstrous embodiment of decay.

Discarding the remaining shreds of who she once was, Farryn took the name of Gorthos, the Beast of Blight. This newly formed abomination spread rot through the forest, turning its plants, animals, and peoples to putrefaction. Now, Gorthos turns her attention to the lands beyond Hartsblight Forest, seeking to impart the blight upon all of Wickermoor Hollow.

Chapter Summary

Infectious fungal spores drift from the tree line of Hartsblight Forest, rapidly spreading through Wickermoor Hollow. The only way to put an end to the advancing disease is to seek out and purge the source of the Hartsblight. Characters drawn to Hartsblight Forest by the Quest Hook later in this chapter have the following goals:

  • Follow the trail of fungal spores to Hartsblight Forest.

  • Find the source of the disease.

  • Destroy Gorthos, the Beast of Blight.

Before running this chapter, familiarize yourself with the motives and history of Gorthos, the Beast of Blight, so that encounters between her and the characters are filled with tension. Understand the features of Hartsblight Forest and the effects of the blight to properly convey the oppressive nature of the diseased forest. Finally, a review of the climactic encounter, “Reign of Decay,” will ensure an intense and cathartic conclusion.

This chapter is designed for four level 8 characters.

Festerhulk.name: Festerhulk
Festerhulk.description:
Festerhulk

Fungal Undead Giant

Habitat: Forest, Swamp, Underground

Treasure: None

Festerhulks are dead giants whose corpses are infested with fungus engorged by the magic of decay. This fungus has consumed and replaced much of the giant’s flesh and now animates the corpse. The heads of these giants are often completely overtaken by repulsive mushrooms and other fungal growths. The spores given off by their infestation can spread to victims killed by festerhulks, giving rise to further Undead.

Secret. Festerhulks shrink from sunlight, which harms the fungus that animates them.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The festerhulk makes two [[/item Fetid Slam]] attacks and uses Slime Mold if available.

Fetid Slam.name: Fetid Slam
Fetid Slam.description: Melee Attack Roll: [[/attack]], reach 10 ft. Hit: [[/damage average]] damage.

Slime Mold.name: Slime Mold
Slime Mold.description: The festerhulk disgorges a mass of ravenous slime mold into an unoccupied space within 20 feet. This mass uses the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.NwQpeeaMxAC3fRft]{Black Pudding} stat block except it is a Plant, and its size is Medium. The mass acts on the festerhulk’s Initiative. It, and any masses it Split into, dries up and dies in 1 hour.

Fungal Step.name: Fungal Step
Fungal Step.description: The festerhulk ignores Difficult Terrain caused by plants or fungi.

Spore Cloud.name: Spore Cloud
Spore Cloud.description: At the end of each of the festerhulk’s turns, each creature in a 5-foot Emanation originating from the festerhulk takes [[/damage average]] damage and has the &reference[poisoned apply=false] condition until the end of its next turn. A Giant or Humanoid killed by this damage rises as a new creature 24 hours later: Festerhulk (if a Giant), @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.NAISFPoNNgUCsEyW]{Zombie} (if a Humanoid).

Sunlight Hypersensitivity.name: Sunlight Hypersensitivity
Sunlight Hypersensitivity.description: The festerhulk takes 10 Radiant damage if it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has Disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

Gloomwood.name: Gloomwood
Gloomwood.description:
Gloomwood

Blighted Treant

Habitat: Forest, Swamp

Treasure: None

Gloomwoods were once treants in service to an archfey, but they were corrupted by a supernatural fungal blight. The growth bores through their trunks and into their souls, making the gloomwoods cruel and vicious, interested only in spreading more decay. Fungal spores drift from their trunks and branches, rotting any flesh and digging into the ground around them to spread the blight.

Secret. Carving the Sylvan name of the forest the gloomwood once called home into the creature’s trunk quells its aggression.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The gloomwood makes two attacks, using [[/item Slam]] or [[/item Fungal Fling]] in any combination.

Slam.name: Slam
Slam.description: Melee Attack Roll: [[/attack]], reach 10 ft. Hit: [[/damage average]] damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the &reference[grappled apply=false] condition (escape DC 16) from one of two branches. Until the grapple ends, the target has the &reference[restrained apply=false] condition.

Fungal Fling.name: Fungal Fling
Fungal Fling.description: Ranged Attack Roll: [[/attack]], range 60/180 ft. Hit: [[/damage average]] damage.

Spore Stomp.name: Spore Stomp
Spore Stomp.description:
Melee Attack Roll: +10, reach 5 ft. Hit: [[/damage average]]damage.

Hit or Miss: Each creature within a 20-foot Sphere centered on the target must make the following saving throw.

Constitution Saving Throw: DC 15.

Failure: 36 ([[/r 8d8]]) Poison damage, and the target has the &reference[poisoned apply=false]condition until the end of its next turn.

Success: Half damage only.

Blighted Aura.name: Blighted Aura
Blighted Aura.description: The ground in a 20-foot Emanation originating from the gloomwood is Difficult Terrain from mushrooms and fungus that grow in the area. A creature that ends its turn in the Emanation takes [[/damage average]] damage.

Carved Past.name: Carved Past
Carved Past.description: As an action, a creature can use a Dagger or Woodcarver’s Tools to carve the name in Sylvan of the ancient home of the gloomwoods into the gloomwood’s trunk. Until the gloomwood finishes a Long Rest, it can’t use its Fungal Fling or Spore Stomp actions.

Fungal Step.name: Fungal Step
Fungal Step.description: The gloomwood ignores Difficult Terrain caused by plants or fungi.

Keeper of the Blight.name: Keeper of the Blight
Keeper of the Blight.description:
Keeper of the Blight

Druid Transformed by Blight

Habitat: Forest, Swamp, Underground

Treasure: Relics

Keepers of the blight arise from Fey beings that dwell in a natural region that becomes overtaken by a supernatural or spiritual rot. Where they once tended the balance and cycles of their home, keepers are consumed by the blight and channel their magic through fungus, mold, and rot, pushing the cycle of life toward death, decay, and the flourishing of things that thrive in gloom.

Secret. The fungus growing throughout keepers of the blight empowers and sustains them, and killing that growth diminishes their power.

Spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
Spellcasting.description:
Spellcasting. The keeper casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 16, +8 to hit with spell attacks):

At Will: @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDruidcraft]{Druidcraft}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplRayofSickn]{Ray of Sickness}

1/Day: @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplBlight0000]{Blight}

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The keeper makes two attacks, using [[/item Blight Staff]] or [[/item Spore Spray]] in any combination, and it uses Rotting Ritual.

Blight Staff.name: Blight Staff
Blight Staff.description: Melee Attack Roll: [[/attack]], reach 5 ft. Hit: [[/damage average]] damage.

Spore Spray.name: Spore Spray
Spore Spray.description: Ranged Attack Roll: [[/attack]], range 60 ft. Hit: [[/damage average]] damage. If the target is a creature, it has the &reference[poisoned apply=false] condition until the end of the keeper’s next turn.

Rotting Ritual.name: Rotting Ritual
Rotting Ritual.description:
The keeper magically creates one of the following effects of its choice. It can’t use the same effect twice in a row.

  • Frenzying Spores. Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 16, a creature the keeper can see within 30 feet.

    Failure: [[/damage average]] damage, and the target must immediately take a Reaction to make a melee or ranged attack against a creature of the keeper’s choice that is within reach or range of the attack.

    Success: Half damage only.

  • Blight Spawn. The keeper magically summons a Rotweaver (lacks a Hunting Horn) in an unoccupied space within 30 feet of itself. The rotweaver takes its turn immediately after the keeper on the same Initiative count, and it obeys the keeper. The rotweaver vanishes after 1 minute, or when it or the keeper dies.

  • Devouring Fungus. Life-sapping fungus sprouts from the ground in a 60-foot radius centered on the keeper. The area is Difficult Terrain, and a creature has the &reference[poisoned apply=false] condition while within the area. The fungus remains for 1 minute, until the keeper uses this effect again, or until it dies.

Blight Dependent.name: Blight Dependent
Blight Dependent.description: If the keeper is targeted by an effect that ends the &reference[poisoned apply=false] condition, it takes [[/damage average]] damage and has Disadvantage on D20 Tests until the end of its next turn.

Fungal Step.name: Fungal Step
Fungal Step.description: The keeper ignores Difficult Terrain caused by plants or fungi.

Druidcraft.name: Druidcraft
Druidcraft.description:
Whispering to the spirits of nature, you create one of the following effects within range.

Weather Sensor. You create a Tiny, harmless sensory effect that predicts what the weather will be at your location for the next 24 hours. The effect might manifest as a golden orb for clear skies, a cloud for rain, falling snowflakes for snow, and so on. This effect persists for 1 round.

Bloom. You instantly make a flower blossom, a seed pod open, or a leaf bud bloom.

Sensory Effect. You create a harmless sensory effect, such as falling leaves, spectral dancing fairies, a gentle breeze, the sound of an animal, or the faint odor of skunk. The effect must fit in a 5-foot Cube.

Fire Play. You light or snuff out a candle, a torch, or a campfire.

Ray of Sickness.name: Ray of Sickness
Ray of Sickness.description:
You shoot a greenish ray at a creature within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes 2d8 Poison damage and has the &Reference[poisoned] condition until the end of your next turn.

Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot. The damage increases by 1d8 for each spell slot level above 1.

Blight.name: Blight
Blight.description:
A creature that you can see within range makes a Constitution saving throw, taking 8d8 Necrotic damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. A Plant creature automatically fails the save.

Alternatively, target a nonmagical plant that isn't a creature, such as a tree or shrub. It doesn't make a save; it simply withers and dies.

Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot. The damage increases by 1d8 for each spell slot level above 4.

Rotweaver.name: Rotweaver
Rotweaver.description:
Rotweaver

Fey Thrall of Rot

Habitat: Forest, Planar (Fey), Swamp

Treasure: Relics

Rotweavers were Fey caretakers of the natural world or fey planes who’ve been corrupted by the power of rot. Rotweavers serve powerful beings of withering and blight as minor acolytes and hunters, working to spread the bounds of their beloved decay.

Secret. The rotweavers’ fey nature still holds; binding them with iron, such as manacles or a chain, mutes their strength.

Staff.name: Staff
Staff.description: Melee Attack Roll: [[/attack]], reach 5 ft. Hit: [[/damage average]] damage.

Call The Rot (Requires Hunting Horn).name: Call The Rot  (Requires Hunting Horn)
Call The Rot (Requires Hunting Horn).description:
Constitution Saving Throw: DC 13, each creature in a 30-foot Cone.

Failure: [[/damage average]] damage, and the target has the &reference[poisoned apply=false] condition until the end of its next turn.

Success: Half damage only.

Failure or Success: The horn call is audible out to 300 feet, and any non-creature plants in the Cone die from fungus and rot

Fungal Step.name: Fungal Step
Fungal Step.description: The rotweaver ignores Difficult Terrain caused by plants or fungi.

Hunting Horn.name: Hunting Horn
Hunting Horn.description: The rotweaver carries a hunting horn. The horn has AC 16, HP 10, and Immunity to Necrotic, Poison, and Psychic damage.

Iron Binding.name: Iron Binding
Iron Binding.description: If the rotweaver has iron wrapped around a part of its body, such as an iron bracelet, Manacles, or Chain (treat any of them as applying @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.tWJLHIL6ZIZUez9k]{Manacles}), the rotweaver can move, take an action, or a Bonus Action, but not all three.

Devil’s Glove.name: Devil’s Glove
Devil’s Glove.description:
Devil’s Glove

Five-Fingered Fungus (Rare wood chips)

Habitat: Forest, Swamp, Underground

Treasure: None

Comprised of five twitching, blood-red tendrils lined with black slime, the devil’s glove fungus feeds voraciously off decaying matter, unwary insects, and small creatures. Resembling a long-fingered hand, they grow from bulbous roots that look like leathery, white eggs and constantly emit an overpowering scent of death and rot. Despite their unpleasant aura, these fungus creatures can form beneficial relationships with others, providing nourishment and resilience in exchange for protection and a ready supply of decaying material to feed upon.

Tendril.name: Tendril
Tendril.description:
Melee Attack Roll: [[/attack]], reach 5 ft. Hit: [[/damage average]] damage, and the devil’s glove attaches to the target. The Beast of Blight

Manifestation of Rot and Decay

Habitat: Forest, Swamp

Treasure: Relics

The Beast of Blight was once known as Farryn of the Greenwood, a druidic protector of the natural cycle who delved into forbidden lore to save her dead lover. Her love was virtuous, but in the end, it caused nothing but pain. Rot overtook the druid, and she is now a monstrous being that spreads and thrives on decay. The Beast of Blight moves effortlessly through decay and spews putrid spores when roused to anger.

Secret. Buried deep within the Beast of Blight, a tiny fragment of Farryn still exists. If shown an image of her lost love, the ignited memory will burn away the rot.

The Beast of Blight’s lair is a cave in the heart of a rotten forest where blight creeps endlessly forth.

Rapid Decay. Within 1 mile of the lair, objects that aren’t worn or carried have vulnerability to necrotic damage, and the length of time in which a dead creature can be brought back to life is halved.
